an10.44:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusināra, in the Forest of Offerings.
an10.44:1.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
an10.44:2.1: “Mendicants, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check five things in themselves and establish five things in themselves.
an10.44:2.2: What five things should they check in themselves?
an10.44:2.3: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
an10.44:2.4: ‘Is my bodily behavior pure? Do I have pure bodily behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?
an10.44:2.5: Is this thing found in me or not?’
an10.44:2.6: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
an10.44:2.7: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own bodily behavior first.’
an10.44:3.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
an10.44:3.2: ‘Is my verbal behavior pure? Do I have pure verbal behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?
an10.44:3.3: Is this thing found in me or not?’
an10.44:3.4: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
an10.44:3.5: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own verbal behavior first.’
an10.44:4.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
an10.44:4.2: ‘Is my heart established in love for my spiritual companions, without resentment?
an10.44:4.3: Is this thing found in me or not?’
an10.44:4.4: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
an10.44:4.5: ‘Come on, venerable, establish your heart in love for your spiritual companions first.’
an10.44:5.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
an10.44:5.2: ‘Am I very learned, remembering and keeping what I’ve learned? These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. Am I very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically?
an10.44:5.3: Is this thing found in me or not?’
an10.44:5.4: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
an10.44:5.5: ‘Come on, venerable, memorize the scriptures first.’
an10.44:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:
an10.44:6.2: ‘Have both monastic codes been passed down to me in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, and well judged in both the rules and accompanying material?
an10.44:6.3: Is this thing found in me or not?’
an10.44:6.4: If it’s not, there will be people who say:
an10.44:6.6: ‘Come on, venerable, train in the code of conduct first.’
an10.44:6.7: These are the five things they should check in themselves.
an10.44:7.1: What five things should they establish in themselves?
an10.44:7.2: ‘I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.
an10.44:7.3: I will speak truthfully, not falsely.
an10.44:7.4: I will speak gently, not harshly.
an10.44:7.5: I will speak beneficially, not harmfully.
an10.44:7.6: I will speak lovingly, not from secret hate.’
an10.44:7.7: These are the five things they should establish in themselves.
an10.44:7.8: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check these five things in themselves and establish these five things in themselves.”
